title: How to Make Corn Casserole

steps.headline: Melt your butter in a microwavable glass dish.
steps.description: Liquefy the butter with short, 30 second intervals. The butter does not need to be hot, just completely melted.

steps.headline: Mix the corns, sour cream, corn muffin mixes, butter, and salt in a large bowl.
steps.description: Using a whisk or spatula, blend all of the ingredients together so that they are combined with no chunks of muffin mix or sour cream. If you want to add spices like garlic powder, black pepper, or hot sauce, add them now.

steps.headline: Lightly grease a 9x13 inch baking dish.
steps.description: Using cooking spray or a small pat of butter, grease an oven-safe dish so that the casserole does not stick when you serve it. You can use a paper towel to evenly spread a light coating of butter across the dish.

steps.headline: Spoon the casserole mix into the dish.
steps.description: Once all of the mixture is in the bowl, use a rubber spatula or spoon to evenly distribute it across the pan. The top should be relatively flat.

steps.headline: Bake for 45-60 minutes.
steps.description: When done, the casserole will be a light golden brown on top. If you prefer a heartier, drier casserole than you can leave it in the oven for closer to an hour.

steps.headline: Sprinkle shredded cheese on top before serving.
steps.description: You can also add the cheese as the casserole finishes cooking -- just apply the cheese to the top of the casserole 5 minutes before you plan on taking it out of the oven.

steps.headline: Coat the top of the casserole with breadcrumbs before cooking.
steps.description: This will create a crunchy, tasty crust on the top of the casserole that complements the soft interior perfectly.

steps.headline: Add eggs to the batter to cook a richer casserole.
steps.description: Many casserole recipes call for eggs because the fat and protein binds the ingredients together, leading to a richer tasting casserole. To add eggs, beat them together with a whisk and add them directly into the casserole with the other ingredients. Never add the eggs to the hot butter, as this can partially cook them before they mix in with everything.

steps.headline: Add cream cheese or shredded cheddar for a cheesy, decadent corn casserole.
steps.description: Simply add the cheese to the rest of the ingredients as you blend them in. You can soften cream cheese to make it easier to mix by leaving it on the counter 20-30 minutes before you begin to cook.

steps.headline: Try out a spicy Mexican corn casserole.
steps.description: This variation on corn casserole makes a great side dish at parties and sporting events. To make it, add 1/2 cup diced jalapenos, bell peppers and green onions to the mix along with a tablespoon of garlic powder, chili powder, and/or crushed chipotle. Top the casserole with 1 cup of shredded pepper jack or cheddar cheese for the last 5 minutes of cooking for a gooey, cheesy upper crust.

steps.headline: Add cooked bacon and chopped scallions for a decadent side dish.
steps.description: This rich but tasty version of corn casserole requires 4-5 chopped slices of bacon and 1/2 cup chopped scallions tossed in with the other ingredients. However, the casserole will not get hot enough to cook the bacon, so you need to cook the bacon beforehand. Garnish with cheddar cheese and/or a handful of fresh scallions.

steps.headline: Sweeten the recipe to make a corn pudding dessert.
steps.description:
The natural sweetness of the corn makes it easy to adapt into a classic southern dessert -- corn pudding. To adjust the recipe for dessert:
Add 1/2 cup sugar, 4 beaten eggs, and 1/2 cup milk. Cook at 400ºF for 1 hour.

text:
Making Corn Casserole Preheat your oven to 350ºF.  Melt your butter in a microwavable glass dish. Liquefy the butter with short, 30 second intervals. The butter does not need to be hot, just completely melted. Mix the corns, sour cream, corn muffin mixes, butter, and salt in a large bowl. Using a whisk or spatula, blend all of the ingredients together so that they are combined with no chunks of muffin mix or sour cream. If you want to add spices like garlic powder, black pepper, or hot sauce, add them now. Lightly grease a 9x13 inch baking dish. Using cooking spray or a small pat of butter, grease an oven-safe dish so that the casserole does not stick when you serve it. You can use a paper towel to evenly spread a light coating of butter across the dish. Spoon the casserole mix into the dish. Once all of the mixture is in the bowl, use a rubber spatula or spoon to evenly distribute it across the pan. The top should be relatively flat. Bake for 45-60 minutes. When done, the casserole will be a light golden brown on top. If you prefer a heartier, drier casserole than you can leave it in the oven for closer to an hour. Sprinkle shredded cheese on top before serving. You can also add the cheese as the casserole finishes cooking -- just apply the cheese to the top of the casserole 5 minutes before you plan on taking it out of the oven. Add eggs to the batter to cook a richer casserole. Many casserole recipes call for eggs because the fat and protein binds the ingredients together, leading to a richer tasting casserole. To add eggs, beat them together with a whisk and add them directly into the casserole with the other ingredients. Never add the eggs to the hot butter, as this can partially cook them before they mix in with everything. Add cream cheese or shredded cheddar for a cheesy, decadent corn casserole. Simply add the cheese to the rest of the ingredients as you blend them in. You can soften cream cheese to make it easier to mix by leaving it on the counter 20-30 minutes before you begin to cook. To make it, add 1/2 cup diced jalapenos, bell peppers and green onions to the mix along with a tablespoon of garlic powder, chili powder, and/or crushed chipotle. Top the casserole with 1 cup of shredded pepper jack or cheddar cheese for the last 5 minutes of cooking for a gooey, cheesy upper crust. Add cooked bacon and chopped scallions for a decadent side dish. This rich but tasty version of corn casserole requires 4-5 chopped slices of bacon and 1/2 cup chopped scallions tossed in with the other ingredients. However, the casserole will not get hot enough to cook the bacon, so you need to cook the bacon beforehand. Garnish with cheddar cheese and/or a handful of fresh scallions. Add 1/2 cup sugar, 4 beaten eggs, and 1/2 cup milk. Cook at 400ºF for 1 hour.
